revision.text:
[[File:Aubrey Valentine Vernon Beaty.jpg|thumb|right|Aubrey Beaty]] '''Aubrey Valentine Vernon Beaty''' [[Military Cross|MC]] (1 February 1916 - 6 December 2009) was a [[British Army]] soldier who won the [[Military Cross]] for his bravery in Holland in 1944 and is thought to be the first British soldier serving with ground forces to cross the German frontier during the closing stages of the Second World War.<ref name=teleg>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/4177276/Aubrey-Beaty.html Aubrey Beaty.] ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', 8 January 2009. Retrieved 20 June 2015.</ref><ref>[http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C9051617 WO 373/51/109.] National Archives. Retrieved 20 June 2015.</ref>
Beaty enlisted in the Royal Artillery in 1939 and saw action in France with the British Expeditionary Force before joining the evacuation from Dunkirk. He subsequently took part in the [[D-Day landings]] in June 1944, and was present at the liberation of Brussels and during the advance on Germany through Holland.<ref name=teleg/>
Beaty was born in Delhi, the son of an officer in the Indian Police. He was educated at Bedford School.<ref name=teleg/>
After being [[demobilised]] in 1947, he joined [[Cond√© Nast Publications]] and became a director of ''[[Vogue Italia]]''. He retired to London.<ref name=teleg/>
